document.docAuthor: Tan, Ming Kai & Japir, Razy & Chung, Arthur Y.C.
document.docTitle: An account on some katydids of the tribes Agraeciini (Conocephalinae) and Meconematini (Meconematinae) from the highlands of western Sabah

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: An account on some katydids of the tribes Agraeciini (Conocephalinae) and Meconematini (Meconematinae) from the highlands of western Sabah

emphasis.docTitle: An account on some katydids of the tribes Agraeciini ( Conocephalinae ) and Meconematini ( Meconematinae ) from the highlands of western Sabah

subSection.paragraph: MING KAI TAN 1, * , RAZY JAPIR 2, 3 & ARTHUR Y.C. CHUNG 2, 4

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Block 207A, Woodleigh Link, Singapore 361207, Republic of Singapore

subSection.paragraph:
2
Forest Research Centre (Sepilok), Sabah Forestry Department, PO Box 1407, 90715 Sandakan, Sabah , Malaysia
3
ï¿½ razy.japir@sabah.gov.my

Based on recent field sampling in the highlands of western Sabah , a new species of
Depressacca Ingrisch, 1998
( Conocephalinae : Agraeciini ) is described from Tenompok,
Depressacca macrolima
sp. nov.
, that can be easily distinguish from two other known congeners by the presence of numerous large and falcate spines on the legs numerous large and falcate spines on its legs. Based on the new material, we also document here the live images and/or new locality records for other katydids of the tribes Agraeciini and Meconematini :
Bispinolakis longicauda Ingrisch, 1998
,
Palaeoagraecia philippina ( Karny, 1926 )
and
Salomona borneensis Willemse, 1959
;
Alloteratura ( Meconemopsis ) longa Gorochov, 2008
,
Borneratura kinabaluana ( Bey-Bienko, 1971 )
and
Rhinoteratura pulchra Gorochov, 2008
.

Key words: Borneo ,
Depressacca
,
East Malaysia
,
new species
,
Tettigoniidae

Western Sabah in Borneo has a mountainous terrain, which includes the Mount Kinabalu as part of the Crocker Range and the Mount Trus Madi of the Trusmadi Range. Many species of orthopterans have been documented from these mountain ranges, even in very recent times (e.g., Ingrisch, 2020 ; Gorochov, 2022 ; Storozhenko, 2023 ). Our field sampling in 2023 had also led to the discovery of new species of crickets ( Tan et al., 2024a , 2024b ). Here we focus on the katydids from the tribes Agraeciini and Meconematini of the subfamilies Conocephalinae and Meconematinae , respectively.

Depressacca Ingrisch, 1998
, a Bornean endemic katydid, was first described from a single species
Depressacca globosa Ingrisch, 1998
from Kalimantan ( Ingrisch, 1998 ). This genus is characterised from other southeast Asian Agraeciini by a green and strongly compressed body ( Ingrisch, 1998 ). In 2020, a second species,
Depressacca kinabalu Ingrisch, 2020
, was described from Mount
Kinabalu ( Ingrisch, 2020 )
. Here, a third species is described from Tenompok, not too far from Mount Kinabalu:
Depressacca macrolima
sp. nov.

We have also photographed for the first time previously described species in their natural environment and collected them, when previously they were known only from dried-preserved and discoloured specimens in the museum. These include
Bispinolakis longicauda Ingrisch, 1998
,
Palaeoagraecia philippina ( Karny, 1926 )
and
Salomona borneensis Willemse, 1959
;
Alloteratura ( Meconemopsis ) longa Gorochov, 2008
,
Borneratura kinabaluana ( Bey-Bienko, 1971 )
and
Rhinoteratura pulchra Gorochov, 2008
.

Material studied here was obtained from opportunistic collection and light-trapping between
31 October and 6 November 2023
in the highlands of different parts of western Sabah : Trusmadi Entomology Camp ( 1184â1228 m .a.s.l.), Bukit Hampuan Forest Reserve (including Mamut Copper Mine) ( 915â1491 m .a.s.l.), Tenompok Forest Reserve ( 1199â1435 m .a.s.l.) and Mesilau River ( 1650 m .a.s.l.). Whenever possible, live specimens were photographed using a Canon EOS 500D digital SLR camera with a compact-macro lens EF 100 mm f/2.8 Macro USM.
FRC Forest Research Centre (Sepilok), Sabah Forestry Department, East Malaysia
ZRC Zoological Reference Collection, Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum, Singapore

materialsCitation.collectorName: M. K. Tan & Japir, M. A. B & D. F. A. Damit

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
EAST MALAYSIA : Sabah State â¢ â ; Tenompok Forest Reserve ; N6.01839 , E116.50276 , 1397.0Â±
10.8 m
.a.s.l.;
6 November 2023
, 20h30; under the foliage of a small tree; coll. M.K. Tan , R . Japir, M.A.B . Asidi & D.F.A. Damit ; SBH.23.192 ( FRC ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The species name refers to the numerous large and falcate spines on the legs characteristics of the species; macro = large, long in Latin and lÄ«m(us) = askew, aslant in Latin.

Diagnosis. The new species differs from both
Depressacca globosa Ingrisch, 1998
from Kalimantan and
Depressacca kinabalu Ingrisch, 2020
from Mount Kinabalu in Sabah by the large, flattened and falcate spines on middle and posterior femora and the dorsal margin of the posterior tibia; the presence of more spines on the legs in general; the presence of black spots on the tegmina; and by the tegmina not tapering towards apex and having the apex rounded (instead of narrow).

The new species differs from the female of
Depressacca globosa
by the shape of the subgenital plate having more slender apical lateral lobes (instead of triangular) and more truncated posterior margin between the lateral lobes (instead of broadly concave); and by the dorsal valves of the ovipositor having their apices more rounded. The new species also differs from the male of
Depressacca kinabalu
(known only from males) by the fastigium being distinctly narrower than and not surpassing the scapus (instead of nearly as wide as and reaching/ surpassing the scapus); and by the anterior margin of the pronotum emarginated in the middle (instead of broadly rounded).
Remarks. Even without a male specimen, the female can be easily differentiated from all other presently known congeners by its diagnostic characters.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Measurements ( â holotype , in mm).
BL = 16.1; BWL = 25.2; HW = 5.0; PL = 5.9; PW = 7.1; TL = 16.9; TW = 4.4; HFL = 10.5; HFW = 3.7; HTL = 10.1 length; OL = 9.1; OW = 2.5.
Ecology. This species was found in forested area in the highlands (more than 1000 m .a.s.l.), dwelling among understory plants.
Distribution. Borneo (Tenompok in Sabah ).

Type locality.
EAST MALAYSIA , Sabah , Tenompok Forest Reserve
.

Remarks. Our â and â specimens were found close to one another around the same time and their morphology is similar to that described by Ingrisch (1998) . The new locality record in Tenompok is not surprising given the proximity to Tenompok to Mount Kinabalu.
Distribution. Borneo (Mount Kinabalu, Tenompok [new locality record] in Sabah ).

Type locality.
EAST MALAYSIA , Sabah , Mount Kinabalu, Sungai Wariu
.

Remarks. We present a new locality record for this species at Mount Trus Madi. The locality record in Mount Trus Madi is not surprising given the seemingly wide distribution of this species.
Distribution. Philippines ( Leyte , Luzon); Borneo (Mount Kinabalu and Mount Trus Madi [new locality record] in Sabah); Micronesia .

Type locality.
PHILIPPINES , Luzon , Manila (lost holotype ), Mayoyao ( neotype )
.

Remarks. We present a new locality record for this species at Bukit Hampuan and provide live images of this species. The locality record in Bukit Hampuan is not surprising given the wide distribution of this species in Borneo.
Distribution. Borneo ( East Kalimantan , Poring, Tawai, Sandakan and Bukit Hampuan [new locality record] in Sabah ).

Type locality.
INDONESIA , Kalimantan Timur [= East Kalimantan ], Upper Mahakkan , Long Bloe-oe , Koetei River
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. Our â specimens show slight variation in the shapes of the male cercus and subgenital plate and genitalic sclerotization ( Fig. 11 ). Gorochov (2016) also found variations in these morphologies among specimens collected from Mount Trus Madi and Mount Kinabalu and these variations overlap with that of our new material from Mount Trus Madi.
Distribution. Borneo (Mount Trus Madi and Mount Kinabalu in Sabah ).

Type locality.
EAST MALAYSIA , Sabah , Mount Trus Madi
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. We present the first live images of this species and a new locality record in Bukit Hampuan.
Distribution. Borneo (Mount Kinabalu, Tenompok, Tenom and Bukit Hampuan [new locality record] in Sabah ).

Type locality.
EAST MALAYSIA , Sabah , Kinabalu National Park
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 13.
Odonturisca epiproctalis Gorochov, 2008
â: habitus in lateral view (A), head and pronotum in dorsal (B) and lateral (C) views, abdominal apex in dorsal (D), dorso-posterior (E), lateral (F) and ventral (G) views, genitalia sclerotization (H). Scale bars: 5 mm (A), 1 mm (BâH).

FIGURE 14.
Rhinoteratura pulchra Gorochov, 2008
â found dead on the ground at Mount Trus Madi.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The tenth abdominal apex, cercus, subgenital plate and genitalia sclerotization of our â specimen resemble the description by Gorochov (2008) . Curiously, the apical segment of the maxillary palpi is uncharacteristic of the genus, being distinctly shorter and stout, resembling that of
Alloteratura
, instead of being equal in length to the subapical segment.
Distribution. Borneo (Mount Trus Madi in Sabah ).

Type locality.
EAST MALAYSIA , Sabah , Mount Trus Madi
.

Proceedings of the Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences, 312 (1 - 2), 26 - 42. https: // doi. org / 10.31610 / trudyzin / 2008.312.1 - 2.26

Distribution. Borneo (Mount Trus Madi in Sabah ).

subSection.paragraph: The authors are grateful to John Lee Yukang, Mohamad Azizan Bin Asidi, Dayang Fazrinah Awg Damit and Jude Bin Petrus Kassim (forest ranger) for field assistance. We also appreciate the assistance provided by the Trusmadi

Entomology Camp: Clara Chong and Jimmy Chew. The permission for research in Sabah was granted by the Sabah Biodiversity Centre (JKM/MBS.1000-2/2 JLD.16 (106) and JKM/MBS.1000-2/3 JLD.5 (40)); Narbert Nasly [District Forestry Officer (DFO) of Keningau] (JPHTN/PSH 100-14/18/2/JLD.17(04)); and Alexander Geivasius (Assistant DFO of Ranau). The work of MKT was supported by the National Geographic Grant NGS-73188R-20.
